{{good article}} [[File:Catalytic triad of TEV protease.png|thumb|360px|The enzyme [[TEV protease]]{{efn|name=TEV}} contains an example of a catalytic triad of residues (red) in its [[active site]]. The triad consists of an [[aspartate]] ([[acid]]), [[histidine]] ([[Base (chemistry)|base]]) and [[serine]] ([[nucleophile]]). The [[Substrate (chemistry)|substrate]] (black) is bound by the [[binding site]] to orient it next to the triad. {{PDB|1lvm}}]]
A '''catalytic triad''' is a set of three coordinated [[amino acid]]s that can be found in the [[active site]] of some [[enzymes]].<ref name=":2" /><ref name="buller1">{{cite journal|last=Buller|first=AR|author2=Townsend, CA|date=Feb 19, 2013|title=Intrinsic evolutionary constraints on protease structure, enzyme acylation, and the identity of the catalytic triad|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=110|issue=8|pages=E653–61|bibcode=2013PNAS..110E.653B|doi=10.1073/pnas.1221050110|pmc=3581919|pmid=23382230}}</ref> Catalytic triads are most commonly found in [[hydrolase]] and [[transferase]] enzymes (e.g. [[protease]]s, [[amidase]]s, [[esterase]]s, acylases, [[lipase]]s and [[β-lactamase]]s). An [[Acid]]-[[Base (chemistry)|Base]]-[[Nucleophile]] triad is a common motif for generating a nucleophilic residue for [[covalent catalysis]]. The [[Amino acid|residues]] form a charge-relay network to polarise and activate the nucleophile, which attacks the [[Substrate (chemistry)|substrate]], forming a [[covalent]] intermediate which is then [[hydrolysed]] to release the [[Product (chemistry)|product]] and regenerate free enzyme. The nucleophile is most commonly a [[serine]] or [[cysteine]] amino acid, but occasionally [[threonine]] or even [[selenocysteine]]. The [[Protein tertiary structure|3D structure]] of the enzyme brings together the triad residues in a precise orientation, even though they may be far apart in the sequence ([[Protein primary structure|primary structure]]).<ref name = "Stryer_Ch9">{{cite book |vauthors=Stryer L, Berg JM, Tymoczko JL | title = Biochemistry | publisher = W.H. Freeman | location = San Francisco | year = 2002 | edition = 5th | isbn = 0-7167-4955-6 | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK21154/ | chapter = 9 Catalytic Strategies | chapter-url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK22526/}}</ref>
As well as [[divergent evolution]] of function (and even the triad's nucleophile), catalytic triads show some of the best examples of [[convergent evolution]]. Chemical constraints on catalysis have led to the same catalytic solution independently evolving in at least 23 separate [[protein superfamily|superfamilies]].<ref name="buller1"/> Their [[enzyme mechanism|mechanism of action]] is consequently one of the best studied in [[biochemistry]].<ref name="Perutz 1992">{{cite book|last=Perutz|first=Max|title=Protein structure. New approaches to disease and therapy|year=1992|publisher=W.H. Freeman and Co|location=New York}}</ref><ref name="cite journal|pmid=7849591">{{cite journal|pmid=7849591 | pmc=2142620 | doi=10.1002/pro.5560031013 | volume=3 | issue=10 | title=Proteolytic enzymes past and present: the second golden era. Recollections, special section in honor of Max Perutz |date=Oct 1994 | journal=Protein Sci | pages=1734–9| author1=Neurath | first1=H }}</ref>
==History== The enzymes [[trypsin]] and [[chymotrypsin]] were first purified in the 1930s.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ohman|first=KP|author2=Hoffman, A |author3=Keiser, HR |title=Endothelin-induced vasoconstriction and release of atrial natriuretic peptides in the rat.|journal=Acta Physiologica Scandinavica|date=April 1990|volume=138|issue=4|pages=549–56|pmid=2141214|doi=10.1111/j.1748-1716.1990.tb08883.x}}</ref> A serine in each of trypsin and chymotrypsin was identified as the catalytic nucleophile (by [[diisopropyl fluorophosphate]] modification) in the 1950s.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dixon|first=Gordon H.|author2=Kauffman, Dorothy L. |author3=Neurath, Hans |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|date=5 March 1958|volume=80|issue=5|pages=1260–1261|doi=10.1021/ja01538a059|title=Amino Acid Sequence in the Region of Diisopropyl Phosphoryl Binding in Dip-Trypsin}}</ref> The structure of chymotrypsin was solved by [[X-ray crystallography#Biological macromolecular crystallography|X-ray crystallography]] in the 1960s, showing the orientation of the catalytic triad in the active site.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Matthews BW, Sigler PB, Henderson R, Blow DM |title = Three-dimensional structure of tosyl-α-chymotrypsin|year = 1967|journal = Nature|volume = 214|pages = 652–656|doi = 10.1038/214652a0|issue = 5089|bibcode = 1967Natur.214..652M }}</ref> Other proteases were sequenced and aligned to reveal a family of related proteases,<ref>{{cite journal|last=WALSH|first=KA|author2=NEURATH, H|title=TRYPSINOGEN AND CHYMOTRYPSINOGEN AS HOMOLOGOUS PROTEINS|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|date=October 1964|volume=52|issue=4|pages=884–9|pmid=14224394|pmc=300366|doi=10.1073/pnas.52.4.884|bibcode=1964PNAS...52..884W}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=de Haën|first=C|author2=Neurath, H |author3=Teller, DC |title=The phylogeny of trypsin-related serine proteases and their zymogens. New methods for the investigation of distant evolutionary relationships.|journal=Journal of Molecular Biology|date=Feb 25, 1975|volume=92|issue=2|pages=225–59|pmid=1142424|doi=10.1016/0022-2836(75)90225-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Lesk|first=AM|author2=Fordham, WD|title=Conservation and variability in the structures of serine proteinases of the chymotrypsin family.|journal=Journal of Molecular Biology|date=May 10, 1996|volume=258|issue=3|pages=501–37|pmid=8642605|doi=10.1006/jmbi.1996.0264}}</ref> now called the S1 family. Simultaneously, the structures of the evolutionarily unrelated [[papain]] and [[subtilisin]] proteases were found to contain analogous triads. The 'charge-relay' mechanism for the activation of the nucleophile by the other triad members was proposed in the late 1960s.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Blow|first=DM|author2=Birktoft, JJ |author3=Hartley, BS |title=Role of a buried acid group in the mechanism of action of chymotrypsin|journal=Nature|date=Jan 25, 1969|volume=221|issue=5178|pages=337–40|pmid=5764436|doi=10.1038/221337a0|bibcode=1969Natur.221..337B}}</ref> As more protease structures were solved by [[X-ray crystallography#Biological macromolecular crystallography|X-ray crystallography]] in the 1970s and 80s, [[homology (biology)|homologous]] (such as [[TEV protease]]) and analogous (such as papain) triads were found.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gorbalenya|first=AE|author2=Blinov, VM |author3=Donchenko, AP |title=Poliovirus-encoded proteinase 3C: a possible evolutionary link between cellular serine and cysteine proteinase families.|journal=FEBS Letters|date=Jan 6, 1986|volume=194|issue=2|pages=253–7|pmid=3000829|doi=10.1016/0014-5793(86)80095-3 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bazan|first=JF|author2=Fletterick, RJ|title=Viral cysteine proteases are homologous to the trypsin-like family of serine proteases: structural and functional implications|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|date=November 1988|volume=85|issue=21|pages=7872–6|pmid=3186696|doi=10.1073/pnas.85.21.7872|pmc=282299|bibcode=1988PNAS...85.7872B}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Phan|first=J|author2=Zdanov, A|author3=Evdokimov, AG|author4=Tropea, JE|author5=Peters HK, 3rd|author6=Kapust, RB|author7=Li, M|author8=Wlodawer, A|author9=Waugh, DS|title=Structural basis for the substrate specificity of tobacco etch virus protease|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|date=Dec 27, 2002|volume=277|issue=52|pages=50564–72|pmid=12377789|doi=10.1074/jbc.M207224200}}</ref> The [[MEROPS]] classification system in the 1990s and 2000s began classing proteases into [[Structural homology|structurally related]] enzyme [[protein superfamily|superfamilies]] and so acts as a database of the convergent evolution of triads in over 20 superfamilies.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rawlings | first1 = N.D. | last2 = Barrett | first2 = A.J. | year = 1993 | title = Evolutionary families of peptidases | url = | journal = Biochem J | volume = 290 | issue = | pages = 205–218 }}</ref><ref name="pmid19892822">{{cite journal |vauthors=Rawlings ND, Barrett AJ, Bateman A |title=MEROPS: the peptidase database |journal=Nucleic Acids Res. |volume=38 |issue=Database issue |pages=D227–33 |date=January 2010 |pmid=19892822 |pmc=2808883 |doi=10.1093/nar/gkp971 |url=}}</ref> Understanding how chemical constraints on evolution led to the convergence of so many enzyme families on the same triad [[geometry|geometries]] has developed in the 2010s.<ref name="buller1"/>
Since their initial discovery, there have been increasingly detailed investigations of their exact catalytic mechanism. Of particular contention in the 1990s and 2000s was whether [[low-barrier hydrogen bonding]] contributed to catalysis,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = A low-barrier hydrogen bond in the catalytic triad of serine proteases|url = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/264/5167/1927|journal = Science|date = 1994-06-24|issn = 0036-8075|pmid = 7661899|pages = 1927–1930|volume = 264|issue = 5167|doi = 10.1126/science.7661899|first = P. A.|last = Frey|first2 = S. A.|last2 = Whitt|first3 = J. B.|last3 = Tobin|bibcode = 1994Sci...264.1927F }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = A Low-Barrier Hydrogen Bond in the Catalytic Triad of Serine Proteases? Theory Versus Experiment|url = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/278/5340/1128|journal = Science|date = 1997-11-07|issn = 0036-8075|pmid = 9353195|pages = 1128–1132|volume = 278|issue = 5340|doi = 10.1126/science.278.5340.1128|first = Elissa L.|last = Ash|first2 = James L.|last2 = Sudmeier|first3 = Edward C. De|last3 = Fabo|first4 = William W.|last4 = Bachovchin|bibcode = 1997Sci...278.1128A }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Agback|first=Peter|last2=Agback|first2=Tatiana|date=2018-07-04|title=Direct evidence of a low barrier hydrogen bond in the catalytic triad of a Serine protease|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-28441-7|journal=Scientific Reports|language=En|volume=8|issue=1|doi=10.1038/s41598-018-28441-7|issn=2045-2322}}</ref> or whether ordinary [[hydrogen bonding]] is sufficient to explain the mechanism.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|title = The low barrier hydrogen bond (LBHB) proposal revisited: The case of the Asp ··· His pair in serine proteases|url = http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/prot.20096|journal = Proteins: Structure, Function, and Bioinformatics|date = 2004-01-01|volume = 55|issue = 3|doi = 10.1002/prot.20096|first = Claudia N.|last = Schutz|first2 = Arieh|last2 = Warshel|pages=711–723}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Energy considerations show that low-barrier hydrogen bonds do not offer a catalytic advantage over ordinary hydrogen bonds|url = http://www.pnas.org/content/93/24/13665|journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|date = 1996-11-26|issn = 0027-8424|pmid = 8942991|pages = 13665–13670|volume = 93|issue = 24|doi = 10.1073/pnas.93.24.13665|first = Arieh|last = Warshel|first2 = Arno|last2 = Papazyan|bibcode = 1996PNAS...9313665W|pmc=19385}}</ref> The massive body of work on the charge-relay, covalent catalysis used by catalytic triads has led to the mechanism being the best characterised in all of biochemistry.<ref name="Perutz 1992" /><ref name="cite journal|pmid=7849591" /><ref name=":8" />
== Function == Enzymes that contain a catalytic triad use it for one of two reaction types: either to [[hydrolysis|split]] a substrate ([[hydrolase]]s) or to transfer one portion of a substrate over to a second substrate ([[transferase]]s). Triads are an inter-dependent set of residues in the [[active site]] of an enzyme and act in concert with other residues (e.g. [[binding site]] and [[oxyanion hole]]) to achieve [[nucleophilic catalysis]]. These triad residues act together to make the [[nucleophile]] member highly [[Reactivity (chemistry)|reactive]], generating a covalent intermediate with the substrate that is then resolved to complete catalysis.
===Mechanism=== Catalytic triads perform [[covalent catalysis]] using a residue as a nucleophile. The reactivity of the nucleophilic residue is increased by the [[functional group]]s of the other triad members. The nucleophile is polarised and oriented by the base, which is itself bound and stabilised by the acid.
Catalysis is performed in two stages. First, the activated nucleophile attacks the [[carbonyl]] carbon and forces the carbonyl oxygen to accept an electron, leading to a tetrahedral [[reaction intermediate|intermediate]]. The build-up of negative charge on this intermediate is typically stabilized by an [[oxyanion hole]] within the active site. The intermediate then collapses back to a carbonyl, ejecting the first half of the substrate, but leaving the second half still covalently bound to the enzyme as an [[acyl-enzyme intermediate]]. The ejection of this first [[leaving group]] is often aided by donation of a proton by the base.
The second stage of catalysis is the resolution of the acyl-enzyme intermediate by the attack of a second substrate. If this substrate is water then the result is hydrolysis; if it is an organic molecule then the result is transfer of that molecule onto the first substrate. Attack by this second substrate forms a new tetrahedral intermediate, which resolves by ejecting the enzyme's nucleophile, releasing the second product and regenerating free enzyme.<ref>{{Cite journal|journal=PhD Thesis|last=Thomas|first=Shafee,|title=Evolvability of a viral protease: experimental evolution of catalysis, robustness and specificity|date=2014|degree=PhD|publisher=University of Cambridge|url=https://www.repository.cam.ac.uk/handle/1810/245207}}</ref>
{{wide image|Triad mechanism.svg|1000px|General reaction mechanism of catalysed by a catalytic triad (black): [[nucleophilic substitution]] at a [[carbonyl]] substrate (red) by a second substrate (blue). First, the enzyme's nucleophile (X) attacks the carbonyl to form a covalently linked acyl-enzyme intermediate. This intermediate is then attacked by the second substrate's nucleophile (X'). If the second nucleophile is the hydroxyl of water, the result is hydrolysis, otherwise the result is [[Transferase#Reactions|group transfer]] of X'.}}
==Identity of triad members== [[File:Triad chemical mech.png|thumb|300px|A catalytic triad charge-relay system as commonly found in proteases. The acid residue (commonly [[glutamate]] or [[aspartate]]) aligns and polarises the base (usually [[histidine]]) which activates the nucleophile (often serine or cysteine, occasionally [[threonine]]). The triad reduces the [[pKa|p''K''<sub>a</sub>]] of the nucleophilic residue which then attacks the substrate. An [[oxyanion hole]] of positively charged usually backbone [[amide]]s (occasionally side-chains) stabilise charge build-up on the substrate [[transition state]].]]
===Nucleophile=== The side-chain of the nucleophilic residue performs covalent catalysis on the [[Substrate (chemistry)|substrate]]. The lone pair of electrons present on the oxygen or sulphur attacks the electropositive [[carbonyl]] carbon.<ref name="Stryer_Ch9"/> The 20 [[amino acid#Standard amino acids|naturally occurring biological amino acids]] do not contain any sufficiently nucleophilic functional groups for many difficult [[catalytic reaction]]s. Embedding the nucleophile in a triad increases its reactivity for efficient catalysis. The most commonly used nucleophiles are the [[hydroxyl]] (OH) of serine and the [[thiol]]/thiolate ion (SH/S<sup>−</sup>) of cysteine.<ref name="buller1" /> Alternatively, [[threonine protease]]s use the [[secondary alcohol|secondary hydroxyl]] of threonine, however due to [[steric hindrance]] of the side chain's extra [[methyl group]] such proteases use their [[N-terminal|''N''-terminal]] amide as the base, rather than a separate amino acid.<ref name=":2" /><ref name="ekici2023"/>
Use of oxygen or sulphur as the nucleophilic atom causes minor differences in catalysis. Compared to [[Nucleophile#Oxygen|oxygen]], [[Nucleophile#sulphur|sulphur]]’s extra [[d orbital]] makes it larger (by 0.4 Å)<ref name="mcgrath92642">{{cite journal|last = McGrath|first = ME|author2 = Wilke, ME|author3 = Higaki, JN|author4 = Craik, CS|author5 = Fletterick, RJ|title = Crystal structures of two engineered thiol trypsins.|journal = Biochemistry|date = Nov 28, 1989|volume = 28|issue = 24|pages = 9264–70|pmid = 2611228|doi = 10.1021/bi00450a005}}</ref> and softer, allows it to form longer bonds (d<sub href="thiol">C-X</sub> and d<sub href="Nucleophile#Oxygen">X-H</sub> by 1.3-fold), and gives it a lower p''K''<sub>a</sub> (by 5 units).<ref name="polgár3232">{{cite journal|last = Polgár|first = L|author2 = Asbóth, B|title = The basic difference in catalyses by serine and cysteine proteinases resides in charge stabilization in the transition state.|journal = Journal of Theoretical Biology|date = Aug 7, 1986|volume = 121|issue = 3|pages = 323–6|pmid = 3540454|doi = 10.1016/s0022-5193(86)80111-4}}</ref> Serine is therefore more dependent than cysteine on optimal orientation of the acid-base triad members to reduce its p''K''<sub>a</sub><ref name="polgár3232" /> in order to achieve concerted [[deprotonation]] with catalysis.<ref name="buller1" /> The low p''K''<sub>a</sub> of cysteine works to its disadvantage in the resolution of the first [[tetrahedral intermediate]] as unproductive reversal of the original nucleophilic attack is the more favourable breakdown product.<ref name="buller1" /> The triad base is therefore preferentially oriented to [[protonate]] the leaving group amide to ensure that it is ejected to leave the enzyme sulphur covalently bound to the substrate N-terminus. Finally, resolution of the acyl-enzyme (to release the substrate C-terminus) requires serine to be re-protonated whereas cysteine can leave as S<sup href="deprotonation">−</sup>. [[Sterically]], the sulphur of cysteine also forms longer bonds and has a bulkier [[van der Waals radius]]<ref name="buller1" /> and if [[mutated]] to serine can be trapped in unproductive orientations in the active site.<ref name="mcgrath92642" />
Very rarely, the [[selenium]] atom of the uncommon amino acid [[selenocysteine]] is used as a nucleophile.<ref name=":0" /> The deprotonated Se<sup>−</sup> state is strongly favoured when in a catalytic triad.<ref name=":0" />
===Base=== Since no natural amino acids are strongly nucleophilic, the base in a catalytic triad [[Chemical polarity|polarise]]s and [[deprotonate]]s the nucleophile to increase its reactivity.<ref name="Stryer_Ch9"/> Additionally, it [[protonate]]s the first [[Product (chemistry)|product]] to aid leaving group departure.
The base is most commonly histidine since its p''K''<sub>a</sub> allows for effective base catalysis, hydrogen bonding to the acid residue, and deprotonation of the nucleophile residue.<ref name=":2">{{cite journal|last=Dodson|first=G|author2=Wlodawer, A|title=Catalytic triads and their relatives.|journal=Trends in Biochemical Sciences|date=September 1998|volume=23|issue=9|pages=347–52|pmid=9787641|doi=10.1016/S0968-0004(98)01254-7}}</ref> [[β-lactamase]]s such as [[TEM-1]] use a [[lysine]] residue as the base. Because lysine's p''K''<sub>a</sub> is so high (p''K''<sub>a</sub>=11), a glutamate and several other residues act as the acid to stabilise its deprotonated state during the catalytic cycle.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Damblon|first=C|author2=Raquet, X |author3=Lian, LY |author4=Lamotte-Brasseur, J |author5=Fonze, E |author6=Charlier, P |author7=Roberts, GC |author8= Frère, JM |title=The catalytic mechanism of beta-lactamases: NMR titration of an active-site lysine residue of the TEM-1 enzyme|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|date=Mar 5, 1996|volume=93|issue=5|pages=1747–52|pmid=8700829|doi=10.1073/pnas.93.5.1747|bibcode=1996PNAS...93.1747D |pmc=39852}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Jelsch|first=C|author2=Lenfant, F |author3=Masson, JM |author4= Samama, JP |title=Beta-lactamase TEM1 of E. coli. Crystal structure determination at 2.5 A resolution.|journal=FEBS Letters|date=Mar 9, 1992|volume=299|issue=2|pages=135–42|pmid=1544485|doi=10.1016/0014-5793(92)80232-6}}</ref> Threonine proteases use their ''N''-terminal amide as the base, since steric crowding by the catalytic threonine's methyl prevents other residues from being close enough.<ref name="brannigan416" /><ref name="cheng1902" />
===Acid=== The acidic triad member forms a hydrogen bond with the basic residue. This aligns the basic residue by restricting its side-chain rotation, and polarises it by stabilising its positive charge.<ref name="Stryer_Ch9" /> Two amino acids have acidic [[Amino acid#Side chains|side chains]] at physiological pH (aspartate or glutamate) and so are the most commonly used for this triad member.<ref name="Stryer_Ch9"/> [[Cytomegalovirus]] protease{{efn|name=Cytomegalovirus}} uses a pair of histidines, one as the base, as usual, and one as the acid.<ref name=":2"/> The second histidine is not as effective an acid as the more common aspartate or glutamate, leading to a lower catalytic efficiency. In some enzymes, the acid member of the triad is less necessary and some act only as a dyad. For example, [[papain]]{{efn|Papain {{MEROPS|clan=CA|fam=C1}}|name = papain}} uses [[asparagine]] as its third triad member which orients the histidine base but does not act as an acid. Similarly, [[hepatitis A]] virus protease{{efn|Hepatitis A virus protease {{MEROPS|clan=PA|fam=C3}}}} contains an ordered water in the position where an acid residue should be.
==Examples of triads== [[File:Triads and their substrates annotated.svg|thumb|500x500px|The range of amino acid residues used in different combinations in different enzymes to make up a catalytic triad for hydrolysis. On the left are the nucleophile, base and acid triad members. On the right are different substrates with the cleaved bond indicated by a pair of scissors. Two different bonds in [[beta-lactam]]s can be cleaved (1 by [[penicillin acylase]] and 2 by [[beta-lactamase]]).]]
===Ser-His-Asp=== The Serine-Histidine-Aspartate motif is one of the most thoroughly characterised catalytic motifs in biochemistry.<ref name="Stryer_Ch9"/> The triad is exemplified by [[chymotrypsin]],{{efn|name=Chymotrypsin|Chymotrypsin {{MEROPS|clan=PA|fam=S1}}}} a model serine protease from the [[PA clan|PA superfamily]] which uses its triad to hydrolyse protein backbones. The aspartate is hydrogen bonded to the histidine, increasing the p''K''<sub>a</sub> of its imidazole nitrogen from 7 to around 12. This allows the histidine to act as a powerful general base and to activate the serine nucleophile. It also has an [[oxyanion hole]] consisting of several backbone amides which stabilises charge build-up on intermediates. The histidine base aids the first leaving group by donating a proton, and also activates the hydrolytic water substrate by abstracting a proton as the remaining OH<sup>−</sup> attacks the acyl-enzyme intermediate.
The same triad has also convergently evolved in [[α/β hydrolase]]s such as some [[lipase]]s and [[esterase]]s, however [[chirality|orientation]] of the triad members is reversed.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sun|first=Yueru|last2=Yin|first2=Shuhui|last3=Feng|first3=Yitao|last4=Li|first4=Jie|last5=Zhou|first5=Jiahai|last6=Liu|first6=Changdong|last7=Zhu|first7=Guang|last8=Guo|first8=Zhihong|date=2014-05-30|title=Molecular Basis of the General Base Catalysis of an α/β-Hydrolase Catalytic Triad|url=http://www.jbc.org/content/289/22/15867|journal=Journal of Biological Chemistry|language=en|volume=289|issue=22|pages=15867–15879|doi=10.1074/jbc.m113.535641|issn=0021-9258|pmid=24737327|pmc=4140940}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Rauwerdink|first=Alissa|last2=Kazlauskas|first2=Romas J.|date=2015-10-02|title=How the Same Core Catalytic Machinery Catalyzes 17 Different Reactions: the Serine-Histidine-Aspartate Catalytic Triad of α/β-Hydrolase Fold Enzymes|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acscatal.5b01539|journal=ACS Catalysis|volume=5|issue=10|pages=6153–6176|doi=10.1021/acscatal.5b01539}}</ref> Additionally, brain [[acetyl hydrolase]] (which has the same fold as a small [[G-protein]]) has also been found to have this triad. The equivalent Ser-His-''Glu ''triad is used in [[acetylcholinesterase]].
===Cys-His-Asp=== The second most studied triad is the Cysteine-Histidine-Aspartate motif.<ref name="buller1"/> Several families of [[cysteine protease]]s use this triad set, for example TEV protease{{efn|name=TEV|TEV protease {{MEROPS|clan=PA|fam=C4}}}} and [[papain]].{{efn|name=papain|Papain {{MEROPS|clan=CA|fam=C1}}}} The triad acts similarly to serine protease triads, with a few notable differences. Due to cysteine's low p''K''<sub>a</sub>, the importance of the Asp to catalysis varies and several cysteine proteases are effectively Cys-His dyads (e.g. [[hepatitis A|hepatitis A virus]] protease), whilst in others the cysteine is already deprotonated before catalysis begins (e.g. papain).<ref name="beveridge1355">{{cite journal|last=Beveridge|first=AJ|title=A theoretical study of the active sites of papain and S195C rat trypsin: implications for the low reactivity of mutant serine proteinases|journal=Protein Science|date=July 1996|volume=5|issue=7|pages=1355–65|pmid=8819168|pmc=2143470|doi=10.1002/pro.5560050714}}</ref> This triad is also used by some amidases, such as [[Peptide-N4-(N-acetyl-beta-glucosaminyl)asparagine amidase|''N''-glycanase]] to hydrolyse non-peptide C-N bonds.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The PUB Domain Functions as a p97 Binding Module in Human Peptide ''N''-Glycanase|journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry|year = 2006|issn = 0021-9258|pmid = 16807242|pages = 25502–25508|volume = 281|issue = 35|doi = 10.1074/jbc.M601173200|first = Mark D.|last = Allen|first2 = Alexander|last2 = Buchberger|first3 = Mark|last3 = Bycroft}}</ref>
===Ser-His-His=== The triad of [[cytomegalovirus]] protease{{efn|name=Cytomegalovirus|Cytomegalovirus protease {{MEROPS|clan=SH|fam=S21}}}} uses histidine as both the acid and base triad members. Removing the acid histidine results in only a 10-fold activity loss (compared to >10,000-fold when aspartate is removed from chymotrypsin). This triad has been interpreted as a possible way of generating a less active enzyme to control cleavage rate.<ref name="ekici2023">{{cite journal|last=Ekici|first=OD|author2=Paetzel, M |author3=Dalbey, RE |title=Unconventional serine proteases: variations on the catalytic Ser/His/Asp triad configuration.|journal=Protein Science|date=December 2008|volume=17|issue=12|pages=2023–37|pmid=18824507|doi=10.1110/ps.035436.108|pmc=2590910}}</ref>
===Ser-Glu-Asp=== An unusual triad is found in seldolisin proteases.{{efn|Seldolisin protease {{MEROPS|clan=SB|fam=53}}}} The low p''K''<sub>a</sub> of the glutamate carboxylate group means that it only acts as a base in the triad at very low pH. The triad is hypothesised to be an [[adaptation]] to specific environments like [[acidic]] [[hot spring]]s (e.g. [[kumamolysin]]) or cell [[lysosome]] (e.g. [[tripeptidyl peptidase]]).<ref name="ekici2023"/>
===Cys-His-Ser=== The [[Endothelium|endothelial]] protease [[VASH1|vasohibin]]{{efn|Vasohibin protease {{MEROPS|clan=CA}}|name=Vasohibin}} uses a cysteine as the nucleophile, but a serine to coordinate the histidine base.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Sanchez-Pulido|first=Luis|last2=Ponting|first2=Chris P.|date=2016-05-15|title=Vasohibins: new transglutaminase-like cysteine proteases possessing a non-canonical Cys-His-Ser catalytic triad|url=https://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article/32/10/1441/1742608|journal=Bioinformatics|language=en|volume=32|issue=10|pages=1441–1445|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btv761|issn=1367-4803|pmc=4866520}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sato|first=Yasufumi|last2=Sonoda|first2=Hikaru|date=2007-01-01|title=The Vasohibin Family: A Negative Regulatory System of Angiogenesis Genetically Programmed in Endothelial Cells|url=http://atvb.ahajournals.org/content/27/1/37|journal=Arteriosclerosis, Thrombosis, and Vascular Biology|language=en|volume=27|issue=1|pages=37–41|doi=10.1161/01.atv.0000252062.48280.61|issn=1079-5642|pmid=17095714}}</ref> Despite the serine being a poor acid, it is still effective in orienting the histidine in the catalytic triad.<ref name=":6" /> Some homologues alternatively have a threonine instead of serine at the acid location.<ref name=":6" />
===Thr-Nter, Ser-Nter and Cys-Nter=== Threonine proteases, such as the [[proteasome]] protease subunit{{efn|name=Proteasome|Proteasome {{MEROPS|clan=PB|fam=T1}}}} and [[Glutamate N-acetyltransferase|ornithine acyltransferases]]{{efn|name=OAT|Ornithine acyltransferases {{MEROPS|clan=PE|fam=T5}}}} use the secondary hydroxyl of threonine in a manner analogous to the use of the serine [[primary alcohol|primary hydroxyl]].<ref name="brannigan416">{{cite journal|last=Brannigan|first=JA|author2=Dodson, G |author3=Duggleby, HJ |author4=Moody, PC |author5=Smith, JL |author6=Tomchick, DR |author7= Murzin, AG |title=A protein catalytic framework with an ''N''-terminal nucleophile is capable of self-activation|journal=Nature|date=Nov 23, 1995|volume=378|issue=6555|pages=416–9|pmid=7477383|doi=10.1038/378416a0|bibcode=1995Natur.378..416B}}</ref><ref name="cheng1902">{{cite journal|last=Cheng|first=H|author2=Grishin, NV|title=DOM-fold: a structure with crossing loops found in DmpA, ornithine acetyltransferase, and molybdenum cofactor-binding domain.|journal=Protein Science|date=July 2005|volume=14|issue=7|pages=1902–10|pmid=15937278|doi=10.1110/ps.051364905|pmc=2253344}}</ref> However, due to the steric interference of the extra methyl group of threonine, the base member of the triad is the ''N''-terminal amide which polarises an ordered water which, in turn, [[deprotonates]] the catalytic hydroxyl to increase its reactivity.<ref name=":2"/><ref name="ekici2023"/> Similarly, there exist equivalent 'serine only' and 'cysteine only' configurations such as [[penicillin acylase]] G{{efn|Penicillin acylase G {{MEROPS|clan=PB|fam=S45}}}} and [[penicillin acylase]] V{{efn|Penicillin acylase V {{MEROPS|clan=PB|fam=C59}}}} which are evolutionarily related to the proteasome proteases. Again, these use their ''N''-terminal amide as a base.<ref name="ekici2023" />
===Ser-''cis''Ser-Lys=== This unusual triad occurs only in one superfamily of amidases. In this case, the lysine acts to polarise the middle serine.<ref name=":5">{{cite journal|last=Shin|first=S|author2=Yun, YS |author3=Koo, HM |author4=Kim, YS |author5=Choi, KY |author6= Oh, BH |title=Characterization of a novel Ser-cisSer-Lys catalytic triad in comparison with the classical Ser-His-Asp triad.|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|date=Jul 4, 2003|volume=278|issue=27|pages=24937–43|pmid=12711609|doi=10.1074/jbc.M302156200}}</ref> The middle serine then forms two strong hydrogen bonds to the nucleophilic serine to activate it (one with the side chain hydroxyl and the other with the backbone amide). The middle serine is held in an unusual ''[[Cis–trans isomerism|cis]]'' orientation to facilitate precise contacts with the other two triad residues. The triad is further unusual in that the lysine and ''cis''-serine both act as the base in activating the catalytic serine, but the same lysine also performs the role of the acid member as well as making key structural contacts.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cerqueira|first=N. M. F. S. A.|last2=Moorthy|first2=H.|last3=Fernandes|first3=P. A.|last4=Ramos|first4=M. J.|date=2017-05-17|title=The mechanism of the Ser-(cis)Ser-Lys catalytic triad of peptide amidases|url=http://pubs.rsc.org/-/content/articlelanding/2017/cp/c7cp00277g/unauth#!divAbstract|journal=Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics|language=en|volume=19|issue=19|doi=10.1039/C7CP00277G|issn=1463-9084|bibcode=2017PCCP...1912343C|pages=12343–12354}}</ref>
===Sec-His-Glu=== The rare, but naturally occurring amino acid [[selenocysteine]] (Sec), can also be found as the nucleophile in some catalytic triads.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Brandt|first=Wolfgang|last2=Wessjohann|first2=Ludger A.|date=2005-02-04|title=The Functional Role of Selenocysteine (Sec) in the Catalysis Mechanism of Large Thioredoxin Reductases: Proposition of a Swapping Catalytic Triad Including a Sec-His-Glu State|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cbic.200400276/abstract|journal=ChemBioChem|language=en|volume=6|issue=2|pages=386–394|doi=10.1002/cbic.200400276|issn=1439-7633}}</ref> Selenocysteine is similar to cysteine, but contains a [[selenium]] atom instead of a sulphur. An example is in the active site of [[thioredoxin reductase]], which uses the selenium for reduction of disulphide in thioredoxin.<ref name=":0" />

==Divergent evolution== The sophistication of the active site network causes residues involved in catalysis (and residues in contact with these) to be highly [[evolutionarily conserved]].<ref>{{cite journal|last = Halabi|first = N|author2 = Rivoire, O|author3 = Leibler, S|author4 = Ranganathan, R|title = Protein sectors: evolutionary units of three-dimensional structure.|journal = Cell|date = Aug 21, 2009|volume = 138|issue = 4|pages = 774–86|pmid = 19703402|doi = 10.1016/j.cell.2009.07.038|pmc=3210731}}</ref> However, there are examples of divergent evolution in catalytic triads, both in the reaction catalysed, and the residues used in catalysis. The triad remains the core of the active site, but it is evolutionarily [[adaptation|adapted]] to serve different functions.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = How far divergent evolution goes in proteins|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0959440X98800730|journal = Current Opinion in Structural Biology|date = June 1998|pages = 380–387|volume = 8|issue = 3|doi = 10.1016/S0959-440X(98)80073-0|first = Alexey G|last = Murzin}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Divergent Evolution of Enzymatic Function: Mechanistically Diverse Superfamilies and Functionally Distinct Suprafamilies|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1146/annurev.biochem.70.1.209|journal = Annual Review of Biochemistry|date = 2001|pmid = 11395407|pages = 209–246|volume = 70|issue = 1|doi = 10.1146/annurev.biochem.70.1.209|first = John A.|last = Gerlt|first2 = Patricia C.|last2 = Babbitt}}</ref> Some proteins, called [[pseudoenzyme]]s, have non-catalytic functions (e.g. regulation by inhibitory binding) and have accumulated mutations that inactivate their catalytic triad.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Murphy|first1=JM|last2=Farhan|first2=H|last3=Eyers|first3=PA|year=2017|title=Bio-Zombie: the rise of pseudoenzymes in biology|url=|journal=Biochem Soc Trans|volume=45|issue=|pages=537–544|doi=10.1042/bst20160400|pmid=28408493}}</ref>
=== Reaction changes === Catalytic triads perform [[covalent catalysis]] via an acyl-enzyme intermediate. If this intermediate is resolved by water, the result is hydrolysis of the substrate. However, if the intermediate is resolved by attack by a second substrate, then the enzyme acts as a [[transferase]]. For example, attack by an [[acyl]] group results in an [[acyltransferase]] reaction. Several families of transferase enzymes have evolved from hydrolases by adaptation to exclude water and favour attack of a second substrate.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Sinapoyltransferases in the light of molecular evolution|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0031942209002970|journal = Phytochemistry|date = October 2009|pages = 1652–1662|volume = 70|series = Evolution of Metabolic Diversity|issue = 15–16|doi = 10.1016/j.phytochem.2009.07.023|first = Felix|last = Stehle|first2 = Wolfgang|last2 = Brandt|first3 = Milton T.|last3 = Stubbs|first4 = Carsten|last4 = Milkowski|first5 = Dieter|last5 = Strack|pmid=19695650}}</ref> In different members of the α/β-hydrolase superfamily, the Ser-His-Asp triad is tuned by surrounding residues to perform at least 17 different reactions.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dimitriou|first=Polytimi S.|last2=Denesyuk|first2=Alexander|last3=Takahashi|first3=Seiji|last4=Yamashita|first4=Satoshi|last5=Johnson|first5=Mark S.|last6=Nakayama|first6=Toru|last7=Denessiouk|first7=Konstantin|date=2017-10-01|title=Alpha/beta-hydrolases: A unique structural motif coordinates catalytic acid residue in 40 protein fold families|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/prot.25338/abstract|journal=Proteins: Structure, Function, and Bioinformatics|language=en|volume=85|issue=10|pages=1845–1855|doi=10.1002/prot.25338|issn=1097-0134}}</ref> Some of these reactions are also achieved with mechanisms that have altered formation, or resolution of the acyl-enzyme intermediate, or that don't proceed via an acyl-enzyme intermediate.<ref name=":7" />
Additionally, an alternative transferase mechanism has been evolved by [[amidophosphoribosyltransferase]]s, which has two active sites.{{efn|amidophosphoribosyltransferase {{MEROPS|clan=PB|fam=C44}}}} In the first active site, a cysteine triad hydrolyses a [[glutamine]] substrate to release free ammonia. The ammonia then diffuses though an [[enzyme tunnel|internal tunnel]] in the enzyme to the second active site, where it is transferred to a second substrate.<ref name="Smith">{{cite journal |vauthors = Smith JL|title = Glutamine PRPP amidotransferase: snapshots of an enzyme in action|journal = Current Opinion in Structural Biology|volume = 8|issue = 6|pages = 686–94|date = Dec 1998|pmid = 9914248|doi = 10.1016/s0959-440x(98)80087-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors = Smith JL, Zaluzec EJ, Wery JP, Niu L, Switzer RL, Zalkin H, Satow Y|title = Structure of the allosteric regulatory enzyme of purine biosynthesis|journal = Science|volume = 264|issue = 5164|pages = 1427–1433|date = Jun 1994|pmid = 8197456|doi = 10.1126/science.8197456|bibcode = 1994Sci...264.1427S }}</ref>
=== Nucleophile changes === [[File:Triad divergence.svg|thumb|500px|[[Divergent evolution]] of [[PA clan|PA clan proteases]] to use different nucleophiles in their catalytic triad. Shown are the serine triad of [[chymotrypsin]]{{efn|name=Chymotrypsin}} and the cysteine triad of TEV protease.{{efn|name=TEV}}]] Divergent evolution of active site residues is slow, due to strong chemical constraints. Nevertheless, some protease [[Protein superfamily|superfamilies]] have evolved from one nucleophile to another. This can be inferred when a superfamily (with the same [[protein structure|fold]]) contains [[protein family|families]] that use different nucleophiles.<ref name=":4" /> Such nucleophile switches have occurred several times during evolutionary history, however the mechanisms by which this happen are still unclear.<ref name="pmid19892822"/><ref name=":4" />

==Convergent evolution== {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 500 | image1 = Triad convergence ser cys.svg | image2 = Triad convergence thr.svg | alt1 = | alt2 =
| caption1 = [[convergent evolution|Evolutionary convergence]] of serine and cysteine protease towards the same catalytic triads organisation of acid-base-nucleophile in different [[protein superfamily|protease superfamilies]]. Shown are the triads of [[subtilisin]],{{efn|Subtilisin {{MEROPS|clan=SB|fam=S8}}}} [[prolyl oligopeptidase]],{{efn|Prolyl oligopeptidase {{MEROPS|clan=SC|fam=S9}}}} TEV protease,{{efn|name=TEV}} and [[papain]].{{efn|name=papain}}
| caption2 = Evolutionary convergence of [[threonine protease]]s towards the same ''N''-terminal active site organisation. Shown are the catalytic threonine of the proteasome{{efn|name=Proteasome}} and ornithine acetyltransferase.{{efn|name=OAT|}} }}
The [[enzymology]] of proteases provides some of the clearest known examples of convergent evolution. The same geometric arrangement of triad residues occurs in over 20 separate enzyme [[Superfamily (proteins)|superfamilies]]. Each of these superfamilies is the result of convergent evolution for the same triad arrangement within a different [[Protein tertiary structure|structural fold]]. This is because there are limited productive ways to arrange three triad residues, the enzyme backbone and the substrate. These examples reflect the intrinsic chemical and physical constraints on enzymes, leading evolution to repeatedly and independently converge on equivalent solutions.<ref name=":2"/><ref name="buller1"/>
=== Cysteine and serine hydrolases === The same triad geometries been converged upon by serine proteases such as the [[chymotrypsin]]{{efn|name=Chymotrypsin}} and [[subtilisin]] superfamilies. Similar convergent evolution has occurred with cysteine proteases such as viral [[C3 protease]] and [[papain]]{{efn|Papain {{MEROPS|clan=CA|fam=C1}}|name = papain}} superfamilies. These triads have converged to almost the same arrangement due to the mechanistic similarities in cysteine and serine proteolysis mechanisms.<ref name="buller1" />

=== Threonine proteases === Threonine proteases use the amino acid threonine as their catalytic nucleophile. Unlike cysteine and serine, threonine is a secondary hydroxyl (i.e. has a methyl group). This methyl group greatly restricts the possible orientations of triad and substrate as the methyl clashes with either the enzyme backbone or histidine base.<ref name="buller1" /> When the nucleophile of a serine protease was mutated to threonine, the methyl occupied a mixture of positions, most of which prevented substrate binding.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pelc|first=Leslie A.|last2=Chen|first2=Zhiwei|last3=Gohara|first3=David W.|last4=Vogt|first4=Austin D.|last5=Pozzi|first5=Nicola|last6=Di Cera|first6=Enrico|date=2015-02-24|title=Why Ser and Not Thr Brokers Catalysis in the Trypsin Fold|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acs.biochem.5b00014|journal=Biochemistry|volume=54|issue=7|pages=1457–1464|doi=10.1021/acs.biochem.5b00014|issn=0006-2960|pmc=4342846}}</ref> Consequently, the catalytic residue of a threonine protease is located at it ''N''-terminus.<ref name="buller1" />
Two evolutionarily independent [[enzyme superfamilies]] with different protein folds are known to use the ''N''-terminal residue as a nucleophile: Superfamily PB (proteasomes using the Ntn fold)<ref name="brannigan416" /> and Superfamily PE ([[acetyltransferase]]s using the DOM fold)<ref name="cheng1902" /> This commonality of [[active site]] structure in completely different protein folds indicates that the active site evolved convergently in those superfamilies.<ref name="buller1" /><ref name="ekici2023" />

revision.text:
The '''evolution of increased competitive ability (EICA) hypothesis''' was first proposed by Bernd Blossey and Rolf Nötzold in 1995 as a way to explain the success of invasive, [[non-indigenous species]] (in particular, plants). Observing that: # there is usually a lag period between the time of introduction of an [[invasive species]] and the point at which it is considered invasive, and # invasive plants seem to be more virulent in habitats into which they have been introduced (as compared to their native habitats), the scientists presumed a sort of [[naturalization]] through modification for non-indigenous plants. Because of a lack of native [[predation]], the scientists reasoned, introduced plants are able to reallocate resources from defense mechanisms into growth and development. Introduced plants can thereby [[evolution|evolve]] to grow taller, produce more [[biomass]], and yield more [[:wikt:viable|viable]] offspring than their native counterparts, according to the hypothesis.<ref>http://www.esf.edu/efb/parry/Blossey_Notzold_1995.pdf</ref>
Blossey and Nötzold tested their hypothesis on ''[[Lythrum salicaria]]'' (purple loosetrife) by potting seeds from plants growing in Ithaca, New York, U.S.A., and Lucelle, Switzerland. The seeds were allowed to [[germinate]] in a lab at Christian-Albrechts University in Kiel, northern Germany, and observed for two years. True to the predictions of the EICA Hypothesis, the plants derived from Ithaca produced significantly more biomass that the plants derived from Lucelle. The ''Lythrum salicaria'' plants derived from Ithaca also grew taller and were significantly less resistant to the root-feeding [[weevil]] present over its native range.
==Significance==
Unlike the notable ideas (concerning the success of invasive non-indigenous organisms) that preceded it, such as the [[enemy release hypothesis]] (ERH) and [[Charles Darwin]]'s [[Habituation Hypothesis]],<ref>Darwin, Charles. On the Origin of Species. Pg. 114–116. Harvard University Press: eighteenth printing, 2003</ref> the EICA hypothesis [[postulate]]s that an invasive species is ''not'' as fit (in its introduced habitat) at its moment of introduction as it is at the time that it is considered invasive. As suggested by the name of the hypothesis (Evolution of Increased Competitive Ability), the hypothesis predicts that much of the invasive potential of an invasive species is derived from its ability to evolve to reallocate its resources.
This idea is troubling{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} in that it adds a new variable to "invasive potential", making it harder to predict whether or not a species will become invasive if it is introduced into a new area. In other words, the EICA hypothesis presents a new environmental safety concern. If its postulates hold, in the long run, [[introduced species]] may have to be more highly regulated than they are at present, because no set of [[Phenotypic trait|traits]] or pattern of introduction can predict the extent to which an organism can reallocate its resources in response to a release from stress.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
==Scientific support and revision==
Since its debut in 1995, Bernd Blossey and Rolf Nötzold's paper, "Evolution of increased competitive ability in invasive nonindigenous plants: a hypothesis" has been met with varying degrees of enthusiasm. The paper has been cited in over 368 articles in [[scientific journals]], including [[review articles]], tests of the hypothesis using different [[model species]], and expansions and reformulations of the hypothesis. Among the model species on which the hypothesis has been evaluated most recently (in its original form) are ''[[Solidago gigantea]]'' (giant goldenrod),<ref>[http://www.springerlink.com/content/e5v2m075252j1202/ Altered patterns of growth, physiology and reproduction in invasive genotypes of Solidago gigantea (Asteraceae)]</ref> ''[[Sapium sebiferum]]'' (Chinese Tallow),<ref>[http://www.springerlink.com/content/l847377740371176/ Increased competitive ability and herbivory tolerance in the invasive plant Sapium sebiferum]</ref> and ''[[Lepidium draba]]'' (whitetop).<ref>[http://www.springerlink.com/content/a0402043431336n7/ No difference in competitive ability between invasive North American and native European Lepidium draba populations]</ref> Of these three model species, the success and behavior of ''Sapium sebifurum'' agreed most closely with the postulates of the EICA Hypothesis, according to the researches conducting the study. In its study, the success and behavior of ''Solidago gigantea'' was only partially explained by the EICA hypothesis, according to its researchers. ''Lepidium draba'' did not seem to follow any of the postulates of the EICA Hypothesis, as the researchers of the study understood them.
Through most of the studies done on the EICA Hypothesis (see examples above), it holds that the introduced populations of invasive plant species are less able to cope with the pressures of specialist [[herbivores]] than native populations of the same species are, suggesting that invasive species ''do'' respond to accelerated [[natural selection]] after being released from the [[selective pressure]] of specialist herbivores and ''do'' have the potential to reallocate resources away from specific forms of defense. However, not all of these introduced populations produce significantly more biomass than the native populations of the same species under laboratory conditions. A study conducted by Bossdorf et al. in 2004 on ''Alliaria petiolata'' (garlic mustard) <ref>[http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1461-0248.2004.00583.x Blackwell Synergy – Ecol Letters, Volume 7 Issue 4 Page 346-353, April 2004 (Article Abstract)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> may lend some insight into this discrepancy. Bossdorf et al. potted seeds from native and introduced populations of ''Alliaria petiolata'' and put them in direct competition with one another in a laboratory setting (i.e. the native and introduced populations were grown on in the same pot of soil, and subjected to the same treatments), and found that in direct competition, the native populations were able to out-compete the invasive populations. Bossdorf et al. proposed that this observation could result from the fact that there is a [[fitness (biology)|fitness]] cost to traits that increase so-called "competitive ability". Under this assumption, invasive populations of ''Alliaria petiolata'' had evolved a higher fitness (similar to ''Lythrum Salicaria'') in their introduced ranges at the cost of certain defense mechanisms ''and'' at the cost of certain aspects of growth and development (dissimilar to ''Lythrum Salicaria''). It could be, therefore, that the EICA Hypothesis is too narrow in scope, and should be reworded to place an emphasis on an invasive species' ability to reallocate its resources in order to procure a fitness advantage that may or may not involve more vigorous growth and development.

[[File:IvyMike2.jpg|right|200px|thumb|The explosion of the [[Ivy Mike]] [[hydrogen bomb]]. The hydrogen bomb is the only known man-made item to achieve fusion energy gain factor larger than 1.]]
The '''fusion energy gain factor''', usually expressed with the symbol '''''Q''''', is the ratio of [[fusion power]] produced in a [[nuclear fusion]] reactor to the power required to maintain the [[Plasma physics|plasma]] in [[steady state]]. The condition of ''Q'' = 1, when the power being released by the fusion reactions is equal to the required heating power, is referred to as '''breakeven'''.
The power given off by the fusion reactions may be captured within the fuel, leading to ''self-heating''. Most fusion reactions release at least some of their energy in a form that cannot be captured within the plasma, so a system at ''Q'' = 1 will cool without external heating. With typical fuels, self-heating in fusion reactors is not expected to match the external sources until at least ''Q'' = 5. If ''Q'' increases past this point, increasing self-heating eventually removes the need for external heating. At this point the reaction becomes self-sustaining, a condition called '''ignition'''. Ignition corresponds to infinite ''Q'', and is generally regarded as highly desirable for a practical reactor design.
Over time, several related terms have entered the fusion lexicon. As a reactor does not cover its own heating losses until about ''Q'' = 5, the term '''engineering breakeven''' is sometimes used to describe a reactor that produces enough electricity to provide that heating. Above engineering breakeven a machine would produce more electricity than it uses, and could sell that excess. A machine that can sell enough electricity to cover its operating costs, estimated to require at least ''Q'' = 20, is sometimes known as '''economic breakeven'''.
{{Asof|2017}}, the record for ''Q'' is held by the [[Joint European Torus|JET]] tokamak in the UK, at ''Q'' = (16 MW)/(24 MW) ≈ 0.67, first attained in 1997. [[ITER]] was originally designed to reach ignition, but is currently designed to reach ''Q'' = 10, producing 500 MW of fusion power from 50 MW of injected thermal power.
==Concept== ''Q'' is simply the comparison of the [[Fusion power|power]] being released by the fusion reactions in a reactor, ''P''<sub>fus</sub>, to the constant heating power being supplied, ''P''<sub>heat</sub>. However, there are several definitions of breakeven that consider additional power losses.
===Breakeven=== In 1955, [[John D. Lawson (scientist)|John Lawson]] was the first to explore the energy balance mechanisms in detail, initially in classified works but published openly in a now-famous 1957 paper. In this paper he considered and refined work by earlier researchers, notably [[Hans Thirring]], [[Peter Thonemann]], and a review article by [[Richard Post]]. Expanding on all of these, Lawson's paper made detailed predictions for the amount of power that would be lost through various mechanisms, and compared that to the energy needed to sustain the reaction.{{sfn|Lawson|1957|p=6}} This balance is today known as the [[Lawson criterion]].
In a successful fusion reactor design, the fusion reactions generate an amount of power designated ''P''<sub>fus</sub>.{{efn|This was denoted ''P''<sub>R</sub> in Lawson's original paper, but changed here to match modern terminology.}} Some amount of this energy, ''P''<sub>loss</sub>, is lost through a variety of mechanisms, mostly convection of the fuel to the walls of the reactor chamber and various forms of radiation that cannot be captured to generate power. In order to keep the reaction going, the system has to provide heating to make up for these losses, where ''P''<sub>loss</sub> = ''P''<sub>heat</sub> to maintain thermal equilibrium.{{sfn|Lawson|1957|pp=8-9}}
The most basic definition of breakeven is when ''Q'' = 1,{{efn|In Lawson's original paper, the term ''Q'' was used to denote the total energy released by the individual fusion reactions, in MeV, and ''R'' referred to the power balance.{{sfn|Lawson|1957|p=6}} Later works used ''Q'' to refer to the power balance, as it is used in this article.}} that is, ''P''<sub>fus</sub> = ''P''<sub>heat</sub>.
Some works refer to this definition as '''scientific breakeven''', to contrast it with similar terms.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=American Nuclear Society |url=http://www.ans.org/pubs/journals/fst/a_22885 |title= The Mirror Fusion Test Facility: An Intermediate Device to a Mirror Fusion Reactor |first=V. N. |last=Karpenko |volume=4 |number=2P2 |date=September 1983 |doi=10.13182/FST83-A22885}}</ref><ref>{{cite conference |title= 17th IAEA Fusion Energy Conference |url=https://cordis.europa.eu/event/rcn/9860_en.html | date =19 October 1998}}</ref> However, this usage is rare outside certain areas, specifically the [[inertial confinement fusion]] field, where the term is much more widely used.
===Extrapolated breakeven=== Since the 1950s, most commercial fusion reactor designs have been based on a mix of [[deuterium]] and [[tritium]] as their primary fuel; others fuels have been studied for a variety of reasons but are much harder to ignite. As tritium is radioactive, highly bioactive and highly mobile, it represents a significant safety concern and adds to the cost of designing and operating such a reactor.<ref>{{cite magazine |magazine=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists |url=https://thebulletin.org/2017/04/fusion-reactors-not-what-theyre-cracked-up-to-be/ |title=Fusion reactors: Not what they’re cracked up to be |date=19 April 2017 |first=Daniel |last=Jassby}}</ref>
In order to lower costs, many experimental machines are designed to run on test fuels of hydrogen or deuterium alone, leaving out the tritium. In this case, the term '''extrapolated breakeven''' is used to define the expected performance of the machine running on D-T fuel based on the performance when running on hydrogen or deuterium alone.<ref name=dict>{{cite web |url=http://www.ees.nagoya-u.ac.jp/~web_dai5/english/B.html |title=Plasma Dictionary |website=Nagoya University |first= M. A. |last=Razzak}}</ref>
The records for extrapolated breakeven are slightly higher than the records for scientific breakeven. Both JET and JT-60 have reached values around 1.25 (see below for details) while running on D-D fuel. When running on D-T, only possible in JET, the maximum performance is about half the extrapolated value.{{sfn|Meade|1997}}
===Engineering breakeven=== Another related term, '''engineering breakeven''', considers the need to extract the energy from the reactor, turn that into electrical energy, and feed that back into the heating system.<ref name=dict/> This closed loop is known as ''recirculation''. In this case, the basic definition changes by adding additional terms to the ''P''<sub>fus</sub> side to consider the efficiencies of these processes.
Most fusion reactions release energy in a variety of forms, mostly [[neutron]]s and a variety of charged particles like [[alpha particle]]s. Neutrons are electrically neutral and will travel out of any [[magnetic confinement fusion]] (MFE) design, and in spite of the very high densities found in [[inertial confinement fusion]] (ICF) designs, they tend to easily escape the fuel mass in these designs as well. This means that only the charged particles from the reactions can be captured within the fuel mass and give rise to self-heating. If the fraction of the energy being released in the charged particles is ''f''<sub>ch</sub>, then the power in these particles is ''P''<sub>ch</sub> = ''f''<sub>ch</sub>''P''<sub>fus</sub>. If this self-heating process is perfect, that is, all of ''P''<sub>ch</sub> is captured in the fuel, that means the power available for generating electricity is the power that is not released in that form, or (1 − ''f''<sub>ch</sub>)''P''<sub>fus</sub>.
In the case of neutrons carrying most of the practical energy, as is the case in the D-T fuel studied in most designs, this neutron energy is normally captured in a "blanket" of [[lithium]] that produces more tritium that is used to fuel the reactor. Due to various [[exothermic]] and [[endothermic]] reactions, the blanket may have a power gain factor a few percent higher or lower than 100%, but that will be neglected here. The blanket is then cooled and the [[cooling fluid]] used in a [[heat exchanger]] driving conventional [[steam turbine]]s. These have an efficiency η<sub>elec</sub> which is around 35 to 40%.
Consider a system that uses external heaters to heat the fusion fuel, then extracts the power from those reactions to generate electrical power. Some fraction of that power, ''f''<sub>recirc</sub>, is needed to recirculate back into the heaters to close the loop. This is not the same as the ''P''<sub>heat</sub> because the self-heating processes are providing some of the required energy. While the system as a whole requires additional power for building climate control, lighting, and the confinement system, these are generally much smaller than the plasma heating system requirements.
Considering all of these factors, the heating power can thus be related to the fusion power by the following equation:
<math>P_{heat} = \eta_{heat} \cdot f_{recirc}\cdot \eta_{elec}\cdot (1-f_{ch})\cdot P_{fus}</math>
where <math>\eta_{heat}</math> is the efficiency that power supplied to the heating systems is turned into heat in the fuel, as opposed to lost in the equipment itself, and <math>\eta_{elec}</math> is the efficiency achieved when turning the heat into electrical power, for instance, through the [[Rankine cycle]].
The fusion energy gain factor is then defined as:
<math> Q_E \equiv \frac{P_{fus}}{P_{heat}} = \frac{1}{\eta_{heat} \cdot f_{recirc}\cdot \eta_{elec}\cdot (1-f_{ch})} </math>
===Ignition=== As the temperature of the plasma increases, the rate of fusion reactions grows rapidly, and with it, the rate of self heating. In contrast, the non-capturable energy losses like x-rays do not grow at the same rate. Thus, in overall terms, the self-heating process becomes more efficient as the temperature increases, and less energy is needed from external sources to keep it hot.
Eventually ''P''<sub>heat</sub> reaches zero, that is, all of the energy needed to keep the plasma at the operational temperature is being supplied by self-heating, and the amount of external energy that needs to be added drops to zero. This point is known as '''ignition'''.
Ignition, by definition, corresponds to an infinite ''Q'', but it does not mean that ''f''<sub>recirc</sub> drops to zero as the other power sinks in the system, like the magnets and cooling systems, still need to be powered. Generally, however, these are much smaller than the energy in the heaters, and require a much smaller ''f''<sub>recirc</sub>. More importantly, this number is more likely to be near constant, meaning that further improvements in plasma performance will result in more energy that can be directly used for commercial generation, as opposed to recirculation.
===Commercial breakeven=== The final definition of breakeven is '''commercial breakeven''', which occurs when the economic value of any net energy left over after recirculation is enough to finance the construction of the reactor.<ref name=dict/> This value depends both on the reactor and the [[spot price]] of electrical power.<ref name=dict/><ref>{{cite web |title=Glossary |website=Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory |url=https://lasers.llnl.gov/education/glossary}}</ref>
Commercial breakeven relies on factors outside the technology of the reactor itself, and it is possible that even a reactor with a fully ignited plasma will not generate enough energy to pay for itself. Whether any of the mainline concepts like [[ITER]] can reach this goal is being debated in the field.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://issues.org/31-4/fusion-research-time-to-set-a-new-path/ |title=Fusion Research: Time to Set a New Path |first=Robert |last=Hirsch |date=Summer 2015 |magazine=Issues in Technology |volume=31 |issue=4}}</ref>
==Practical example== Most fusion reactor designs being studied {{asof|2017|lc=yes}} are based on the D-T reaction, as this is by far the easiest to ignite, and is energy dense. However, this reaction also gives off most of its energy in the form of a single highly energetic neutron, and only 20% of the energy in the form of an alpha. Thus, for the D-T reaction, ''f''<sub>ch</sub> = 0.2. This means that self-heating does not become equal to the external heating until at least ''Q'' = 5.
Efficiency values depend on design details but may be in the range of η<sub>heat</sub> = 0.7 (70%) and η<sub>elec</sub> = 0.4 (40%). The purpose of a fusion reactor is to produce power, not to recirculate it, so a practical reactor must have ''f''<sub>recirc</sub> = 0.2 approximately. Lower would be better but will be hard to achieve. Using these values we find for a practical reactor ''Q'' = 22.
==Transient vs. continual== Many early fusion devices operated for microseconds, using some sort of pulsed power source to feed their [[magnetic confinement fusion|magnetic confinement]] system and used the confinement as the heating source. Lawson defined breakeven in this context as the total energy released by the entire reaction cycle compared to the total energy supplied to the machine during the same cycle.{{sfn|Meade|1997}}
Over time, as performance increased by orders of magnitude, the reaction times have extended from microseconds to seconds, and in [[ITER]], on the order of minutes. In this case definition of "the entire reaction cycle" becomes blurred. In the case of an ignited plasma, for instance, P<sub>heat</sub> may be quite high while the system is being set up, and then drop to zero when it is fully developed, so one may be tempted to pick an instant in time when it is operating at its best to determine ''Q''. A better solution in these cases is to use the original Lawson definition averaged over the reaction to produce a similar value as the original definition.{{sfn|Meade|1997}}
However, there is a complication. During the heating phase when the system is being brought up to operational conditions, some of the energy released by the fusion reactions will be used to heat the surrounding fuel, and thus not be released. This is no longer true when the plasma reaches its operational temperature and enters thermal equilibrium. Thus, if one averages over the entire cycle, this energy will be included as part of the heating term, that is, some of the energy that was captured for heating would otherwise have been released in P<sub>fus</sub> and is therefore not indicative of an operational ''Q''.{{sfn|Meade|1997}}
Operators of the JET reactor argued that this input should be removed from the total:
<math> Q* \equiv \frac{P_{fus}}{P_{heat} - P_{temp}} </math>
where:
<math> P_{temp} = \frac{dWp}{dt} </math>
That is, P<sub>temp</sub> is the amount of energy needed to raise the internal energy of the plasma. It is this definition that was used when reporting JET's record 0.67 value.{{sfn|Meade|1997}}
Some debate over this definition continues. In 1998, the operators of the [[JT-60]] claimed to have reached ''Q'' = 1.25 running on D-D fuel, thus reaching extrapolated breakeven. However, this measurement was based on the JET definition of Q*. Using this definition, JET had also reached extrapolated breakeven some time earlier.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www-jt60.naka.jaea.go.jp/english/html/exp_rep/rep46.html |title=JT-60U Reaches 1.25 of Equivalent Fusion Power Gain |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130106002827/http://www-jt60.naka.jaea.go.jp/english/html/exp_rep/rep46.html |archive-date=6 January 2013 |date=7 August 1998 |accessdate=5 December 2016}}</ref> If one considers the energy balance in these conditions, and the analysis of previous machines, it is argued the original definition should be used, and thus both machines remain well below break-even of any sort.{{sfn|Meade|1997}}
==Scientific breakeven at NIF== Although most fusion experiments use some form of magnetic confinement, another major branch is [[inertial confinement fusion]] (ICF) that mechanically presses together the fuel mass (the "target") to increase its density. This greatly increases the rate of fusion events and lowers the need to confine the fuel for long periods. This compression is accomplished by heating a lightweight capsule holding the fuel so rapidly that it explodes outwards, driving the fuel mass on the inside inward in accordance with [[Newton's third law]]. There are a variety of proposed "drivers" to cause the implosion process, but to date most experiments have used [[laser]]s.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://kfe.fjfi.cvut.cz/~limpouch/plazma/Pfalzner_Introduction_ICF.pdf |title=An Introduction to Inertial Confinement Fusion |first=S. |last=Pfalzner |publisher=CRC Press |date=2006 |pages=13-24}}</ref>
Using the traditional definition of ''Q'', ''P''<sub>fus</sub> / ''P''<sub>heat</sub>, ICF devices have extremely low ''Q''. This is because the laser is extremely inefficient; whereas <math>\eta_{heat}</math> for the heaters used in magnetic systems might be on the order of 70%, lasers are on the order of 1.5%. For this reason, [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]] (LLNL), the leader in ICF research, has proposed another modification of ''Q'' that defines ''P''<sub>heat</sub> as the energy delivered by the driver, as opposed to the energy put into the driver. This definition produces much higher ''Q'' values, and changes the definition of breakeven to be ''P''<sub>fus</sub> / ''P''<sub>laser</sub> = 1. On occasion, they referred to this definition as "scientific breakeven".<ref>{{cite techreport |title=Status of the NIF Project |first=Edward |last=Moses |date=4 May 2007 |publisher=Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory |page=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |journal=Applied Optics |first=H. G. |last=Ahlstrom |title= Laser fusion experiments, facilities, and diagnostics at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory |volume=20 |issue=11 |doi=10.1364/AO.20.001902 |date= June 1981 |page=1903}}</ref> This term was not universally used, other groups adopted the redefinition of ''Q'' but continued to refer to ''P''<sub>fus</sub> = ''P''<sub>laser</sub> simply as breakeven.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=Uw91AgAAQBAJ |title=Assessment of Inertial Confinement Fusion Targets |publisher= National Academies Press |date=July 2013 |page=45, 53}}</ref>
On 7 October 2013, the BBC announced that LLNL had achieved scientific breakeven in the [[National Ignition Facility]] (NIF) on 29 September.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-24429621 |date=7 October 2013 |title=Nuclear fusion milestone passed at US lab |first=Paul |last=Rincon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |website=Nature |url=https://www.nature.com/news/laser-fusion-experiment-extracts-net-energy-from-fuel-1.14710 |title=Laser fusion experiment extracts net energy from fuel |first=Philip |last=Ball |date=12 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |website=HiPER |url=http://www.hiper-laser.org/News%20and%20events/index.html |title=Latest Fusion Results from the National Ignition Facility |date=13 February 2014}}</ref> In this experiment, ''P''<sub>fus</sub> was approximately 14 kJ, while the laser output was 1.8 MJ. By their previous definition, this would be a ''Q'' of 0.0077. However, for this press release, they re-defined ''Q'' once again, this time equating ''P''<sub>heat</sub> to be only the amount energy delivered to "the hottest portion of the fuel", calculating that only 10 kJ of the original laser energy reached the part of the fuel that was undergoing fusion reactions. This release has been heavily criticized in the field.<ref>{{cite web |website=FIRE |url=https://fire.pppl.gov/ICF_Scientific_Breakeven_LLNL2.pdf |title=Scientific Breakeven for Fusion Energy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |website=Science |url=https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2013/10/fusion-breakthrough-nif-uh-not-really |title=Fusion "Breakthrough" at NIF? Uh, Not Really … |first=Daniel |last=Clery |date=10 October 2013}}</ref>

page.title: Geography and ecology of the Everglades
